capacity_payment.rate: CPUC-approved rate in Schedule E-CBP tariff (specific $/kW-month rates not publicly disclosed in web sources; likely based on CAISO market rates which exceeded $13/kW-month in 2023, with CPM soft offer cap at $7.34/kW-month as of June 2024)
capacity_payment.recipient: paid to aggregator, who determines customer compensation independently

performance_payment.rate: Energy payment for event curtailment (specific $/kWh not disclosed)
performance_payment.conditions: If no CBP Events called during operation month, monthly energy payment is zero

penalty.conditions: Charged to aggregator for energy usage over FSL (Firm Service Level) during curtailment; penalty severity varies based on shortfall magnitude

event_parameters.max_events_per_month: More than 6 events per month allowed under 'Elect' option
event_parameters.event_trigger: Triggered when PG&E receives market award from CAISO for a PDR (Proxy Demand Resource) based on aggregator's offer price for nominated portfolio

eligibility.minimum_load: 100 kW aggregate per PDR (PG&E combines multiple customers via aggregator to meet CAISO requirement)
eligibility.meter_requirements: Interval Meter (MV90 or SmartMeter) recording 15-minute intervals, remotely readable by PG&E
excluded_customers: Customers receiving power from WAPA or other 3rd parties not DA/CCA

baseline_methodology: FSL (Firm Service Level) methodology; similar programs use 10-day baseline (Monday-Friday, excluding PG&E holidays and event days) with optional day-of adjustment (+/- 20% cap based on first 3 of 4 hours prior to event); FSL can be no more than 85% of customer's highest monthly maximum demand during summer on-peak and winter partial-peak periods over past 12 months

program_structure.enrollment: Aggregator-managed program; customers enrolled through third-party aggregators
program_structure.aggregator_role: Aggregator submits monthly capacity nominations, determines customer incentives, manages portfolio, submits offer prices to CAISO, and bears penalty risk for underperformance
program_structure.caiso_integration: Tied to CAISO PDR (Proxy Demand Resource) market awards; events triggered by day-ahead market results

battery_suitability.justification: Battery storage is highly suitable for CBP due to: (1) Day-ahead notification (by 5 PM) provides sufficient time for battery scheduling and SOC management; (2) 4-hour maximum event duration aligns well with typical commercial battery systems (2-4 hour duration); (3) Program explicitly allows all customer types including Net metered and Auto DR, indicating technology-agnostic approach; (4) No minimum load per customer (only 100 kW aggregate PDR requirement) enables smaller batteries to participate via aggregation; (5) Battery can precisely control discharge to stay below FSL, minimizing penalty risk; (6) Integration with CAISO wholesale markets (PDR) means batteries can potentially stack value with energy arbitrage and ancillary services; (7) Summer-only program (May-Oct) aligns with peak demand season when battery economics are strongest; (8) Aggregator model provides professional management of complex CAISO market interactions; (9) 15-minute interval metering matches battery telemetry capabilities; (10) FSL baseline methodology (85% of peak demand) is favorable for batteries which can reliably deliver full nameplate discharge capacity.

research_notes: Key findings: (1) CBP is fundamentally a wholesale market participation program - aggregators bid customer load reductions into CAISO day-ahead PDR market; (2) Specific $/kW capacity rates are CPUC-approved but not disclosed in web sources, likely vary based on market conditions; CAISO system capacity exceeded $13/kW-month in 2023; (3) Energy payments similarly not disclosed but tied to CAISO market clearing prices; (4) FSL penalty structure ($6/kWh for over-consumption) creates strong incentive for precise load reduction - batteries excel at this precision; (5) Program operates May-October only, no winter events; (6) Aggregator bears financial risk and manages CAISO complexity, making this accessible to customers; (7) CAISO PDR minimum 100 kW enables small batteries to participate via aggregation; (8) Program integrates with broader CAISO demand response ecosystem including resource adequacy; (9) No explicit battery storage exclusions found; residential eligibility suggests behind-the-meter systems are allowed; (10) Relationship to other PG&E programs unclear - customers should evaluate CBP vs Base Interruptible Program vs direct CAISO participation vs retail arbitrage opportunities. Alternative consideration: Larger battery systems (>1 MW) might achieve better economics through direct CAISO market participation as non-generator resources (NGR) or Proxy Demand Resources rather than through utility aggregator programs.
research_quality_notes: Moderate completeness: (1) Program structure, eligibility, and event parameters well documented; (2) Critical gap: specific capacity payment rates ($/kW-month) not accessible - Schedule E-CBP PDF could not be extracted; (3) Critical gap: energy payment rates ($/kWh) not disclosed in public sources; (4) Baseline methodology inferred from similar programs but CBP-specific FSL calculation details not confirmed; (5) CAISO PDR context well researched with CPM soft offer cap ($7.34/kW-month) providing benchmark; (6) Battery eligibility inferred from program design and lack of exclusions rather than explicit statement; (7) Aggregator compensation structure confirmed but rates are privately negotiated; (8) No customer case studies or actual participation data found; (9) Tariff document exists but specific rates require direct access to readable PDF; (10) Score of 6/10 reflects good understanding of program mechanics but missing critical financial details needed for ROI analysis.
